results.title: Lost in space
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hopkins, Carla Fay, Akiva Goldsman, Mark W Koch and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: In the not too distant future, earth is on the verge of total collapse and survival lies on colonising outer space. All hope rests on the Robinson family, whose mission is to establish life on Alpha Prime, the only other habitable planet in the galaxy. However when their spacecraft is sabotaged by a traitor, they find themselves lost in space and flying headlong into some out of this world dangers. Cast includes William Hurt, Gary Oldman, Matt LeBlanc, Mimi Rogers, Heather Graham and Lacey Chabert.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Hopkins, Carla Fay, Akiva Goldsman, Mark W Koch and New Line Cinema

results.title: Lost in La Mancha
results.creator_credit: Louis Pepe, Keith Fulton, Lucy Darwin, Low Key Pictures and Quixote Films
results.brief_description: A documentary about the failed production of a feature film directed by Terry Gilliam that was to be called “The Man Who Killed Don Quixote”. The documentary takes us through the pre-production process from storyboards and script development to costume and set design. Leading up to the start of production all that is missing are the actors! The all-star cast would have included Johnny Depp, Jean Rochefort and Vanessa Paradis. Only six days into production the film strikes a series of events of bad luck, which include Acts of God, cast illness, insurance complications and staff quitting. After developing the film for ten years, director Terry Gilliam looses ownership of his script and the whole project is abandoned. A very useful tool to those teaching/studying filmmaking, this documentary explains the process of feature filmmaking and its inherent risks. Includes interviews with key members of the production, including Australian 1st AD Phil Patterson. Narrated by Jeff Bridges. Two-disc set with over four hours of special features.

results.title: Lost in a crowd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
In this essay on loneliness, five characters in search of someone are sitting on a train. The film shows how each has unsuccessfully tried to remedy their situation. All five share a common problem yet as the train goes down the line not a word is spoken.

results.title: Lost horizon
results.brief_description: Based on the international best-seller by James Hilton, this Hollywood classic made ‘Shangri La’ a household word. Ronald Colman, one of the few stars to successfully make the transition from the silent era to “talkies”, stars as a British consul who, together with a planeload of American and English passengers, flees war-torn China only to be hijacked to Tibet where he is taken to a remote idyllic Utopian community in the Himalayas where he has been chosen to become the next High Lama.

results.title: Lost honour of Katharina Blum = Die verlorene Ehre der Katharina Blum
results.creator_credit: Volker Schlondorff, Margarethe Von Trotta, Willi Benninger, WDR, Paramount Pictures, Orion Pictures Corporation, Cinema International Corp and Bioskop Film
results.brief_description: Katharina Blum (Angela Winkler) spends the night with Ludwig Goetten (Jurgen Prochnow), a new acquaintance who is, unknown to her, under police surveillance. This one night stand has serious repercussions for Katharina who is brought in for police questioning. Her basic civil rights ignored at every turn, Katharina is relentlessly grilled about her relationship with her one-night stand. As a result she loses her job, her friends, and her standing in the community. Unsatisfied with this, the police go after Katharina’s family. Her story is also exploited by the ‘yellow press’, which hounds her and depicts her as everything from loose woman to communist moll. And so, through the mirror of a manipulative press, Katharina becomes the most hated woman in Germany. The film achieves a compelling portrait of Germany in the mid-seventies (the lead years), during which the fight against the Red Army Faction led a number of State agencies to use any means possible to fight terrorism, while a manipulative right wing press sent an entire country in a frenzy over the breakdown of law and order. This originally made for TV production is adapted from the novel by Heinrich Boll (itself based on actual events). In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Lost highways: the roadside photography of Richard Szymczuk
results.brief_description: A fascinating look into the world of Australian photographer Richard Szymczuk and his passion for the urban/industrial landscape of Geelong and its surrounding environs. Since 1987 Richard has been on a mission photographing old rundown servos, milkbars, general stores, billboards, factories, recording history before it literally disappears or is replaced. His photographs have become an art form of social expression and reflect today’s society of economic rationalism. In the film Richard talks about his background, his work and his philosophy on life reflecting on the ever-changing landscape as evidenced by the many examples of his photographic works and his revisits to some of the original locales that feature throughout the documentary. Photographed by Simon Anderson with Simon Kirby and music by Steven Baker.

results.title: Lost Highway
results.brief_description: A tormented jazz musician finds himself lost in an enigmatic story involving murder, surveillance, gangsters, doppelgangers, and an impossible transformation inside a prison cell.
results.description: A tormented jazz musician finds himself lost in an enigmatic story involving murder, surveillance, gangsters, doppelgangers, and an impossible transformation inside a prison cell.
description_for_label: A tormented jazz musician finds himself lost in an enigmatic story involving murder, surveillance, gangsters, doppelgangers, and an impossible transformation inside a prison cell.

results.title: Lost highway
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, Mary Sweeney, Tom Sternberg, Deepak Nayar, Asymmetrical Productions and CiBy 2000
results.brief_description: Since his success with “Eraserhead” in the early 1980s, David Lynch has developed a reputation as one of the most creative and experimental film artist’s working in contemporary cinema. “Lost Highway” continues his exploration of the horror film and film noir, in which he uses sound, music and images to convey some of the surreal beauty and terror of dreams. Beginning with a cliched noir story of a jazz musician (Bill Pullman) who is being cheated upon by his femme fatale wife (Patricia Arquette), the film then fiendishly betrays our expectations by having the musician exchange identities with a young auto-mechanic (Balthazar Getty), who is entranced by a gangster’s girlfriend (also played by Arquette). As in his groundbreaking television series, “Twin Peaks”, Lynch is more interested in the logic of dreams than he is in classical narrative. The power of his work is that he is able to maintain an atmosphere of terror and suspense as surely as horror masters such as Hitchcock and Polanski. If “Lost Highway” defies easy categorization, it is a film experience that remains to haunt the viewer, and it is one of the more challenging and consistent of post-modern film works that have attempted to breathe new life into the film noir genre by both celebrating and questioning the conventions of the genre (i.e. is “Lost Highway” satirizing or taking to the limits the “evil” of the femme fatale?). The film includes a disturbing goth soundtrack by artists such as Nine Inch Nails, Marilyn Manson (who also appears in the film), David Bowie, Smashing Pumpkins and Lou Reed. The script is co-written by Lynch and long-time collaborator, Barry Gifford. The original music score is by Lynch’s favoured musician, Angelo Badalamenti.

results.title: Lost book found
results.brief_description: The result of over five years of Super 8 and 16mm filming on New York City streets, ‘Lost Book Found’ melds documentary and narrative approaches into a complex meditation on city life. The piece revolves around a mysterious notebook filled with obsessive listings of places, objects, and incidents which serve as the key to a hidden city. It is a city on unconsidered geographies and layered artefacts - the relics of low-level capitalism and the debris of countless forgotten narratives. The project stems from the filmmaker’s first job in New York - working as a pushcart vendor on Canal Street. As usual, Cohen shot in hundreds of locations using unobtrusive equipment and generally without any crew. Influenced by the work of Walter Benjamin, Cohen created ‘an archive of undirected shots and sounds, then set out to explore the boundary’ between genres. During the process Cohen said, ‘I found connections between the street vendor, Benjamin’s ‘flaneur’ and my own work as an observer and collector of ephemeral street life’.
